2. A 12-year-old male presented with complete absence of the nose and significant visual impairment due to bilateral microphthalmia, first noted in infancy. He had a history of chronic mouth breathing and episodic cyanosis during sleep, suggestive of upper airway obstruction. Developmental evaluation revealed delayed language acquisition and mild intellectual disability. Physical examination confirmed total arhinia with no external nasal structures, alongside small, malformed eyes with limited visual acuity. Endoscopic assessment showed severely narrowed nasal passages with no functional airway. Brain MRI revealed absent olfactory bulbs and hypoplasia of the optic nerves, correlating with his sensory deficits. No cardiac, renal, or limb abnormalities were noted, supporting isolated Bosma Arhinia Microphthalmia Syndrome. The patient was enrolled in a multidisciplinary care program focused on surgical airway reconstruction, ocular prosthetics, and speech therapy to optimize functional outcomes.

output:
